centralQuestion: Is it in the interest of the United States to interfere in the wars of other nations?

reasons.description: To prevent mass atrocities and protect civilians under the 'responsibility to protect' when regimes threaten or commit large-scale violence.
To deter aggressors, uphold alliance commitments, and maintain U.S. credibility and leadership in the international order.

sources.title: Atlantic Council: 'Donald Trump’s promise of strong US leadership should begin with Ukraine'

reasons.description: To protect global trade routes and energy flows where disruptions threaten U.S. and allied economic security.

sources.title: Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS): 'The Global Economic Consequences of the Attacks on Red Sea Shipping Lanes'
Associated Press: 'The Strait of Hormuz is a vital route for oil. Closing it could backfire on Iran'

reasons.description: To counter transnational terrorist threats where limited, targeted military action or support to partners can disrupt violent extremist groups.

sources.title: RAND Corporation: 'The Air War Against The Islamic State'

objections.description: Interventions risk bypassing legal and constitutional guardrails, undermining sovereignty and setting dangerous precedents.

sources.title: International Crisis Group: 'Bending the Guardrails: U.S. War Powers After 7 October'

objections.description: External interventions frequently produce unintended consequences that worsen conflict dynamics or empower harmful actors.

sources.title: Chatham House: 'Why peacebuilding fails and what to do about it'

objections.description: Civilian harm, escalation risks, and transparency problems can erode legitimacy and fuel backlash against U.S. interests.

sources.title: Council on Foreign Relations: 'Nine Months of Coalition Air Strikes Against the Islamic State'

objections.description: Interventions often have unforeseen impacts on local legitimacy and governance, complicating stabilization and prolonging violence.

sources.title: Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI): 'Towards legitimate stability in CAR and the DRC'

objections.description: Military action can be counterproductive compared with humanitarian and diplomatic efforts, with costs outweighing likely benefits.

sources.title: The Guardian: 'Sudan’s forgotten war is bloody and horrifying - but US bombs aren’t the way to stop it'

research.title: 'Going in When It Counts? Military Intervention and the Outcome of Civil Conflicts'
research.description: Stephen E. Gent examines when external military intervention affects civil war outcomes, finding that interventions can decisively shape results under certain conditions while also risking prolonged conflict; open-access PDF available.

research.title: 'Alliances and Civil War Intervention'
research.description: Jesse C. Johnson analyzes how alliance commitments influence states’ decisions to intervene in civil wars, showing that alliance structures can increase the likelihood of intervention; open-access PDF available.

research.title: 'Train the World: The Logics of U.S. Foreign Military Training'
research.description: K. J. M. Joyce explores why and how the United States uses foreign military training as a form of intervention and the strategic logics behind it; open-access article.

research.title: 'International Military Interventions and Transnational Terrorist Backlash'
research.description: James A. Piazza evaluates whether foreign military interventions generate increased transnational terrorism against interveners, finding evidence of backlash dynamics in the public abstract.

research.title: 'Identifying Pathways to Peace in Civil Wars'
research.description: Manfred Mross studies strategies and conditions that lead to negotiated settlements and durable peace in civil wars, with implications for external involvement; abstract publicly available.
